title: Britney Spears Sells Music Catalogue for $200 Million
summary: Pop icon Britney Spears has sold the rights to her entire music catalogue to the independent publisher Primary Wave for approximately $200 million. This sale, which occurred on December 30, includes hits such as '...Baby One More Time', 'Oops!... I Did It Again', 'Toxic', and 'Gimme More', spanning nine studio albums since her 1999 debut. Spears, who has sold over 150 million records globally, made this move after ending a 13-year conservatorship in 2021, a legal arrangement that gave her father control over her finances and personal life. In January 2024, she stated she would 'never return to the music industry', with her last release being a 2022 duet with Elton John. The sale aligns with a trend among high-profile artists like Bruce Springsteen and Justin Bieber, who have also sold their catalogues for substantial sums. Primary Wave, founded by Lawrence Mestel, has previously acquired rights to estates of artists like Notorious BIG and Prince. Details of the transaction remain private, highlighting Spears' ongoing efforts to reclaim autonomy post-conservatorship.

background_read: Britney Spears rose to fame in the late 1990s as a teen pop sensation, with her debut album '...Baby One More Time' becoming a global phenomenon. Over her career, she has released multiple hit albums and singles, solidifying her status as a best-selling artist. However, her personal life has been marked by challenges, including a highly publicized conservatorship from 2008 to 2021, where her father managed her affairs amid concerns about her mental health. This legal arrangement sparked widespread debate and a 'Free Britney' movement advocating for her autonomy. The sale of her music catalogue represents a significant financial and personal milestone, as it allows her to monetize her past work while distancing herself from the industry. This trend of artists selling catalogues has grown in recent years, driven by desires for lump-sum payments and estate planning, with companies like Primary Wave capitalizing on the value of iconic music legacies.
